choices.D: RESTCONF supports XML and NETCONF supports JSON.
choices.C: RESTCONF and NETCONF supports JSON and XML.
choices.A: RESTCONF supports JSON and XML and NETCONF supports XML.
choices.B: RESTCONF supports XML and NETCONF supports JSON and XML.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true for Cisco IOS XE Software?

discussion.content: A is correct. Netconf only uses XML, restconf can use either JSON or XML

Selected Answer: A
A - NETCONF only XML, RESTCONF - JSON or XML

questions.answer_description: PUT is used to update the snmp network ID. The access has to be community and not users. Therefore, option B is correct.

discussion.content:
Answer B:
Explanation:
The type of SNMP access. Can be one of 'none' (disabled), 'community' (V1/V2c), or 'users' (V3).
It uses PUT to update the value
source: https://developer.cisco.com/meraki/api/#!update-network-snmp-settings

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which NETCONF statement type is represented by +--rw address* [ip]?

discussion.content:
A seems correct Answer
https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-nmdsdt-netconf-rfc7895bis-00.html#rfc.section.1.2
Brackets "[" and "]" enclose list keys.
Abbreviations before data node names: "rw" means configuration data (read-write) and "ro" state data (read-only).
Symbols after data node names: "?" means an optional node, "!" means a presence container, and "*" denotes a list and leaf-list.

Selected Answer: A
+--rw address* [ip] is a List entry (note “*”). Therefore, the answer A seems the correct answer.

Reference: https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2020/pdf/R6BGArNQ/TECNMS-2401.pdf page 32

questions.answer_description: Symbols after data node names: "?" means an optional node, "!" means a presence container, and "*" denotes a list and leaf-list.

questions.question_text: The automation engineer must replace device configuration using RESTCONF. How is this configured using the Python library Requests?

discussion.content: Answer C is correct. PUT is used to replace a configuration entirely. PATCH is used to make partial changes.

Selected Answer: C
C - Put - Update
